stem: A 65-year-old man presents with significant weight loss and complains of cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain. He has been taking analgesics for shoulder pain for several months. On examination, he has a constricted pupil and a drooping eyelid on the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
disc:
Pancoast tumors or superior sulcus tumors initially present as upper limb pain. Pain is mainly due to the involvement of the brachial plexus, pleura, and first and second ribs.

Horners syndrome refers to ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, enophthalmos, and anhydrosis. It may be present in up to 50% of the patients with Pancoast tumors.

Neurological deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb may develop gradually in addition to these findings. Supraclavicular lymphadenopathy and significant weight loss are also seen in up to 35% of the patients.

Due to the anatomical favorability diagnosis can be obtained with a percutaneous needle biopsy. Histology is predominantly nonsmall cell lung cancers.
